ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to skim dense academic texts as well as personal narratives for key points. How to write an analytical argumentative academic paper that builds off various theorists

Through Cultures of Travel, I learned about tourism (and travel in general) and its imperialist, neocolonialist, and otherwise problematic consequences. A huge skill I gained was engaging effectively with theory -- in our three written assignments this semester, we had to engage with multiple theoretical texts while analyzing (1) a personal experience, (2) a movie, and (3) primary sources of our own choosing. I also greatly improved my writing through these assignments.
Too many to list, but we had many thought-provoking discussions of travel and its effects on people. I learned a lot about theorists of travel and methods to analyze travel.
How to apply theory to real life.

A deep-dive into modern tourist practices, why they are/can be harmful, and why people crave unfamiliar experiences in the first place. We study humanitarianism, colonialism, sex tourism, masculinity, hunting, and lots more.

Knowledge of various theories of travel and interaction with the other, skills on critical analysis and theory application, and insights into the way the world is set up (I know that's broad, just trust me).

I learned about privileged forms of travel and the ways structures of power continue to perpetuated privileged mobility. I also learned how to apply complex theory to an analysis of primary sources on travel.
Learning how to actually engage with theorists to support your own thesis instead of just recognising similarities between the source youre writing an essay about and the materials you read in class.
I learned how to read and apply theories and critiques.  I also feel my writing was greatly improved in this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a wonderful course. The material is extremely interesting -- the theory we had to read and discuss was very insightful and even fun to read. Professor TZB is wonderful, both in terms of teaching and being a kind and accommodating professor; I had so much fun in the class.
The main strength of this course is certainly the professor, and she utilized a wide repertoire of theorists to help her students be able to analyze travel in a critical lens,

Strengths:
TZB, they're an amazing professor. 

Weaknesses:
I wish we did more peer editing and / or turned in rough drafts for comments

The strengths of this course are the professor and the flexibility. It could be improved by having a bit more time for discussion, and a bit more of an opportunity for exploration and discussion, but honestly I think you'd miss out on some stuff with that so perhaps nevermind.
There were the perfect number of writing assignments. The readings were always interesting and pertinent.

I feel this course is amazing in every way.  Our discussions were interesting and TZB always planned for a fun class.  Even through a zoom screen the energy TZB cultivated in the classroom was palpable.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was great online. I really appreciated having live discussions and breakout room sessions with my classmates, and it didn't feel to different from a normal, in person course.

We used breakout rooms quite a bit, which made it a lot easier/less intimidating to get to know our classmates on a smaller scale. Also, I'm not sure if this counts as a practice, but professor TZB scheduled a day where she came outside and met all of us on campus to just have a chat which was so so kind and nice!

What succeeded was the flexibility and openness to letting us take things more at our own pace and letting us do different things, and what could be improved would perhaps be a little more early opportunities for in person interaction.

The breakout rooms and small discussion/slide shows were incredibly helpful when it came to synthesizing material from discussions and readings, as were the Canvas discussion posts. I only wish we had the opportunity to make more class/group slide shows.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Regardless of major. This class was super engaging and even though it was online, it was super conducive to the formulation of friendships and getting to know others in your class which is great for your first year. I was remote and I was able to do that so I imagine an in person experience will be even better. This class is an interesting survey of various critical theories such as capitalism, feminism, imperialism, homonationalism, etc applied to the context of travel but can be applied elsewhere. I will say though that this was a lot more work than I expected though and I averaged 10 hours a week spent on this course with more being spent when writing papers. I feel like my writing has improved in the clarity of my argumentative writing but drafting was often a time consuming process. TZB is also a fantastic resource in making everyone engaged, supporting everyone, creating an inclusive classroom environment, and being a great resource for one on one meetings.

Yes! I would 100% recommend this course. It was one of the best decisions of my semester. I had so much fun in the class, and found the material very stimulating and interesting. Professor TZB is wonderful and this first-year seminar is as well.

101%, out of the 8 classes I've taken so far this is by far my favorite. The topic is surprisingly applicable to most of life, it's interesting (the first week of content might be rough but its foundational) & TZB is an amazing professor.
Yes yes yes!!! It truly challenges your perception of why we desire experiences such as study abroad, etc.

Yes! Please take this class, if you have absolutely any interest in the rest of the world, at all, or if you've ever heard about it, again at all. It provides such a great perspective on the world, one which would be so easy to miss if you don't have access to these readings or this professor to show you. I think also as the world globalizes and as you have opportunities to engage with people of different cultures and perspectives, it is also incredibly important to be mindful of what that means and how to do so. Finally, I do think there are elements of this class that have the potential to make you a better person, if you're willing to think about what that means and work towards it.

Yes! This course was absolutely wonderful. Professor TZB truly cared about helping her students improve their writing and close reading skills. The readings were always pertinent and interesting. It completely changed the way I understand race, sexuality, gender, and other aspects of identity that inform the way individuals move throughout the world. If you are at all interested in travel and other forms of colonial knowledge production, this is the course for you! Even if you are simply interested in travel, this course will also transform the way you view the world and how you travel in the future.
Yes if you are good with doing readings and want to be exposed to a good learning environment where you can really think about culture and contemporary power dynamics in the world.

Please take this class or any with TZB.  TZB is such a wonderful professor and although I was very  interested in the material we were learning, I can excited every day because of TZB's energy and teaching chops.

comments: n/a
